Courses.Title: Physiology of Exercise I
Courses.Description: A study of principles of physiology as they apply to human movement. Topics discussed include: training principles, energy metabolism, characteristics of skeletal muscle, neurological aspects of human movement, muscle contraction and fatigue, respiration and circulation. Laboratory sessions expose students to the techniques used in measuring the energy systems.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: You must have CHEM 1210, BIOL 2011, 2012, and 2030 completed to take the course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 3010L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 3010 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Physiology of Exercise II
Courses.Description: A continuation of Kinesiology 3010. Topics include: body composition, obesity, and nutrition; training for performance; factors affecting performance; laboratory assessment of performance; and thermoregulation, exercise, and the environment. Students will utilize laboratory assessments to develop an exercise/lifestyle prescription for a volunteer client.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Introductory Statistics
Courses.Description:
Introduction to basic statistical concepts and methods as they apply to the field of Kinesiology. Major topics include: exploratory data analysis, descriptive statistics and an introduction to inferential statistics.

Only one basic undergraduate statistics course may be taken for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 3030L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 3030L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Adapted Physical Activity
Courses.Description: An introduction to issues associated with adapted physical activity, viewed from the lifespan approach. Topics include examination of issues in inclusion; discussion of motor characteristics of individuals diagnosed with different developmental and neurological deficits; exploration of different intervention approaches; and the introduction of basic concepts in measurement as applied to the process of assessment of atypically functioning individuals. Opportunity is provided for a practicum placement in a community agency.

Courses.Title: Soc of Sport & Physical Act II
Courses.Description: A continuation of Kinesiology 2079 that examines contemporary issues pertaining to sport and physical activity. Particular emphasis will be given to the relationship between sport and economics, mass media, politics, globalization, social problems (cheating and violence), religion and the future of sport.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 2079 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Health Promo & Weight Mgmt
Courses.Description: Using a health promotion lens, students examine issues surrounding weight management from individual and societal perspectives. Contributory factors such as health behaviours (e.g., physical activity, diet) and the obesogenic environment are explored. Research evidence involving interventions for enhancing health in this context is discussed.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 1113 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Musculoskeletal Injuries I
Courses.Description: A comprehensive study of musculoskeletal injuries with emphasis on etiology, pathology, basic treatment and prevention of peripheral joint injuries. Encompasses a practical approach including laboratory experience.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: BIOL 2011, 2012, and 2030 need to be completed to take this  course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 3134L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 3134 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Musculoskeletal Injuries II
Courses.Description: An advanced and comprehensive study of musculoskeletal injuries with emphasis on etiology, diagnosis, basic treatment and prevention of spinal, facial and abdominal injuries. Expanding upon the foundation established in Kine 3134, the student is introduced to a variety of pathological conditions and diseases that affect both the spinal and peripheral joint regions. A clinical reasoning approach is enhanced through in-class practical experiences.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take KINE-3134; Minimum grade 50;
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Research Processes
Courses.Description: An introduction to quantitative and qualitative research methods used in the fields of kinesiology and health.  Knowledge acquired will assist the student with planning and evaluation of research, and prepare them for the research project conducted via Kinesiology 4220/4230.

Courses.Title: History of Sport in Canada
Courses.Description: See Department of History, History Courses, History 3318, for full course description.

Courses.Title: Nutrition Phys Act & Health
Courses.Description: An introduction to the science of nutrition. Topics include nutrition in everyday life, basic nutritional principles, and their application. The biological foundations of nutrition are explored, along with emerging topics and controversies regarding nutritional practices.

Courses.Title: Skill Acquisition
Courses.Description: Provides an opportunity to explore the issues associated with acquisition of movement skills. Focus is on theoretical aspects of motor learning as well as on practical issues associated with structuring and implementation of a skill acquisition session. Students are responsible for devising a lesson plan for the physical activity of choice, and teaching a particular skill/activity to their peers.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 3710L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 3710 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Exercise Prescription
Courses.Description: Provides students with practical and theoretical experiences in exercise prescription for apparently healthy individuals.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 3711L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 3711 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Environmental Physiology
Courses.Description: Through theoretical and laboratory experiences, students examine the environment's influence on physiological responses to maintaining homeostasis and performance during exposure to stressors such as thermal (hot and cold), diving (hyperbaria), high altitude (hypoxia), and microgravity (e.g., space flight). Strategies to prepare for acute and chronic exposure to environmental stress, and how diseased states may alter the normal human response, will be discussed.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE-3010 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE-4010L needs to be regsitered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE-4010 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Advanced Motor Control
Courses.Description: Different models and theories of motor control and coordination exist which at the behavioral level, are embedded in philosophical and methodological assumptions of two paradigms: information processing and dynamic systems. Students learn about models which attempt to solve a redundancy problem in motor behaviour, as well as models emphasizing the importance of feedback and feedforward processing to movement organization.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 2035 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Psyc of Physical Activity II
Courses.Description: A survey of topics within the field of physical activity psychology. Emphasis is placed on topics that build off the field's foundational concepts and that can be applied by exercise, sport, and health practitioners and professionals to enhance health, well-being, and performance. Processes, techniques, and approaches utilized in physical activity psychology research are integrated into the course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Lifestyle Counselling
Courses.Description: An interactive course focused on the theoretical foundations and application of lifestyle counselling models as they relate to health promotion and behaviour change.  Students will acquire professional communication and counselling skills through evaluating and creating client-based scenarios within a team setting.

Courses.Title: Clinical Exercise Physiology
Courses.Description: An advanced course linking basic human physiology principles to acute and chronic adaptations to physical activity in both health and disease. Emphasis is on the critical interpretation and reporting of current research in skeletal muscle and cardiovascular physiology.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Outdoor Experience
Courses.Description:
An outdoor hiking/camping experience is completed in fourth year. Includes a four session preparation component, as well as two days and nights of hiking/camping experience. This trip will occur in late September/early October.

An additional fee (see Miscellaneous Fees) is required for this non-credit required course.

Courses.Title: Individual Research Project
Courses.Description:
Under the guidance and supervision of a Kinesiology faculty or staff member, a student develops, conducts, and communicates a research project that is founded in, and intended to make a significant contribution to, the Kinesiology knowledge-base. Enrolment in the course is determined, in part, through a competitive application process.

Only one of Kinesiology 4220 or 4230 may be completed for credit. A minimum of 75% overall Kinesiology average is required to participate in Kinesiology 4220.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Team Research Project
Courses.Description:
Under the guidance and supervision of a Kinesiology faculty member, students work in small teams to develop, conduct, and communicate research projects that are founded in, and intended to contribute to, the Kinesiology knowledge-base. Multiple sections are available, with each generally focused on a specific Kinesiology sub-discipline. Enrolment in a section is determined, in part, through a balloting process.

Although a half-course equivalent, this course is scheduled over both fall and winter terms. Enrolment is limited in each section. Only one of Kinesiology 4220 or 4230 may be completed for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Ergonomics
Courses.Description: Introduces the student to the study of human movement in both workplace and domestic environments. A multi-disciplinary approach is used to study human movement efficiency and interactions with machines. Standard quantitative measurement techniques are introduced for evaluation and assessment of human performance in workplace settings.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: You must have BIOL 2011, 2012 and 2030 completed to take  this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 4130L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 4310 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Advanced Issues in Nutrition
Courses.Description: An analysis of current research and guidelines in medical nutrition therapy for the prevention and management of chronic diseases, including diabetes, obesity, cardiovascular disease, and cancer. The roles of macro- and micro-nutrients and of non-nutrients in disease prevention are explored. A critical review and group discussion approach is used to aid in understanding dietary and lifestyle principles.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: KINE 3610 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Principles Commun & Leadership
Courses.Description: Communication and leadership are explored in personal, social, and cultural contexts, providing students with a foundation for effectively receiving, interpreting, sharing, and presenting information.  Students investigate the development of skills such as conflict resolution, ethical decision-making, and professionalism as well as the application of those skills within the practice of kinesiology.

Courses.Title: Career Exploration
Courses.Description:
The application of theory and practice of Kinesiology in a community based placement situation. Students experience the reality of a career in Kinesiology or a related field. Placements are selected from a diverse and varied pre-approved list of community education placement partners. Participants gain experience under the supervision of an on-site supervisor and are engaged in information sharing seminars with fellow students throughout the course. A combination of community placement hours and career seminar classes are required.

Restricted to third and fourth year Kinesiology students who have a minimum of 75% cumulative Kinesiology average. After initial registration, students are required to submit a written request, including background information to be approved, to remain in Kinesiology 4713. A current police criminal reference check may be required before placement. May not be taken by students in the Honours Bachelor of Kinesiology Co-op Education Program Option.

Courses.Title: Canadian Constitutional Law
Courses.Description: Examines the distribution of legislative powers between the federal parliament and the provincial legislatures and the impact of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. IPC skills components: factum for appeal and oral arguments.

Courses.Title: Contract Law
Courses.Description: Explores the basic principles of contract law from formation of a contract to remedies available for breach of contract. IPC skills components: negotiation and contract drafting

Courses.Title: Legal Research and Writing
Courses.Description:
Introduces the fundamentals of legal research and writing.  It includes instruction in using legal databases, legal citation, issue determination, legal reasoning and analysis, and techniques for clear, correct, and persuasive writing.

IPC skills component:  research memorandum

Restricted to students in year 1 of the JD program

Courses.Title: Criminal Law
Courses.Description: Criminal Law is a survey course intended to introduce students to substantive and procedural aspects of Canadian criminal law. The "substantive" portion of the course is concerned with defining "criminal" conduct and the recognition of defences. The "procedural" portion provides a broad overview of the criminal process, examines the impact of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, and explores protections for individual rights under criminal law. IPC skills component: oral submissions.

Courses.Title: Tort Law
Courses.Description:
Examines the law of torts (civil wrongs), including intentional torts (such as assault, battery, and trespass), nuisance, negligence and strict liability, as well as consideration of compensation for damage and injury.

IPC skills components: client interview and memo to file.

Courses.Title: Foundations of Canadian Law
Courses.Description:
Provides an introduction to foundational principles and skills such as the sources of Canadian law including Indigenous law, common law, equity, statute law and international law, principles of statutory interpretation, as well as essential skills related to the study of law.

IPC skills component:  case brief.

Courses.Title: Indigenous Law
Courses.Description:
Introduces students to world views from the perspective of Aboriginal Peoples in Canada and how these perspectives fit within the legal system.

IPC skills component:  sharing circle with a negotiation focus.

Restricted to students in the JD program only

Courses.Title: Indigenous Perspectives
Courses.Description: Indigenous Perspectives will introduce students to Indigenous culture, traditions and perspectives through speakers, dialog and experience-based opportunities.

Courses.Title: Property Law
Courses.Description: Examines law associated with real and personal property with special emphasis on Aboriginal and natural resource law issues.

Courses.Title: Aboriginal Law
Courses.Description:
Examines Aboriginal rights under the Common Law, Constitution and relevant legislative provisions that affect Aboriginal peoples.

IPC skills component:  negotiation.

Restricted to students in the JD program only.

Courses.Title: Civil Practice
Courses.Description:
A skills based course that requires students to carry a civil action from the commencement of an action through to trial and appeal. IPC skills component: drafting various litigation documents and oral advocacy.

Restricted to students in the JD program only.

Courses.Title: Wills and Estates
Courses.Description:
Instruction on substantive law related to estate planning, administration from the initial interview to drafting and file management skills. IPC skills component: drafting an instrument.

Restricted to students in year 2 or 3 of the JD program

Courses.Title: Administrative Law
Courses.Description:
Examines the statutory and Common Law procedural protections governing the manner in which administrative decisions are made.

Restricted to students in JD program only.

Courses.Title: Environmental Law
Courses.Description:
Designed to familiarize students with various legal regimes and legal issues concerning the environment.

Restricted to students in the JD program only.

Courses.Title: Labour & Employment Law
Courses.Description:
Employment law is concerned with regulation of the individual employment relationship through the Common Law and statutory regimes. Labour law deals with the law governing the collective bargaining relationship between unions and employers, as well as the rights and duties arising under a collective agreement.

Restricted to students in the JD program only

Courses.Title: Business Organizations
Courses.Description:
Provides an introduction to the various ways of structuring a business and examines legal issues surrounding business practices. IPC skills component: opinion letter.

Restricted to students in JD program only.

Courses.Title: Spec Topics in Aboriginal Law
Courses.Description:
Special topics in Aboriginal law will be explored.

Restricted to students in JD program only.

Courses.Title: Insurance Law
Courses.Description:
Insurance law is the underlying foundation of Tort law in Ontario. Examines the principles that govern insurance contract disputes and focuses on how Insurance law works from a practical perspective (including acting for and against insurers). Specific topics to include: automobile, liability, property, life, broker liability, and the duties of both insurers and insureds.

May only be taken by students in the 2nd or 3rd year.

Courses.Title: Evidence
Courses.Description:
Examines the admissibility of evidence in civil and criminal cases.

Restricted to students in the JD program only.

Courses.Title: Remedies
Courses.Description:
A study of the law relating to damages and various equitable and Common Law remedies.

Restricted to students in the JD program only.

Courses.Title: Special Topics in Law
Courses.Description:
Special topics in law will be explored.

Restricted to students in JD program only

Courses.Title: Law Journal Editor
Courses.Description:
Involves undertaking the position of Managing Editor of the Lakehead Law Journal, subject to the direction of the Co-Editors-in-Chief, which will include secondary edits on papers accepted for publication.

Elective in second or third year.

Courses.Title: Clinical Law
Courses.Description:
Experiential learning opportunities for students in year 2 or 3 of the program who are approved by the Director of the Clinic.

May only be taken by students in the 2nd or 3rd year who are approved by the Director of the Clinic.

Courses.Title: Clinical Law
Courses.Description:
Experiential learning opportunities for students in year 2 of the program who are approved by the Director of the Clinic.

May only be taken by students in the 2nd year who are approved by the Director of the Clinic.

Courses.Title: Bankruptcy and Insolvency Law
Courses.Description:
Provides a comprehensive overview of the insolvency regimes in Canada, focusing primarily on the study of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act and the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act.  It considers the various insolvency regimes available under both statutes, including personal and corporate bankruptcies and consumer, and commercial proposals.

Restricted to students in the second or third year of the JD Program.

Courses.Title: Advanced Criminal Law Advocacy
Courses.Description:
Combines learning the nuts and bolts of advocacy skills, with practicing the use of those skills, from the start of a criminal jury trial to its conclusion. The curriculum includes advocacy training in examining and cross-examining witnesses, addressing juries, making motions, conducting bail hearings and appeals, as well as written argument. Each student will be marked on their participation in class and the presentation of practicums for each stage of the criminal trial.

Restricted to students in the second or third year of the JD Program.

Courses.Title: Trusts Law
Courses.Description:
The law of trusts is concerned with relationships where one person, called a trustee, is compelled by equity to hold property for the benefit of another person or persons. It examines the equitable obligations binding the trustee as well as the concept of a fiduciary and fiduciary duties, including the fiduciary obligation of the Crown to Indigenous Peoples. Other topics may include the comparison of trusts to other legal relationships, express trusts, purpose trusts including charitable trusts, administration of trusts, liability of trustees; remedies related to trusts; resulting trusts, constructive trusts, the taxation of trusts, and evolving uses of trusts.

Restricted to students in the second or third year of the JD Program.

Courses.Title: Family Law
Courses.Description:
An overview of key legal issues regarding familial relationships and family breakdown in Canadian society including child custody, support, and protection. 

IPC skills component:  drafting an affidavit.

May only be taken by students in the 2nd or 3rd year.

Courses.Title: Directed Research Paper
Courses.Description:
On approval of the Dean, in appropriate cases, a student may be permitted to do a substantial research paper. The topic can include new research or may build upon research done for another purpose. Minimum 10,000 words, excluding footnotes and bibliography.

Upper year students are eligible to take this course with permission of the Dean of the Faculty.

Courses.Title: Practice Placement
Courses.Description:
A full time practical placement for a period of 15 weeks in which students have extended opportunity to observe and practice under the supervision of an authorized lawyer. The practice placement is recognized by the Law Society of Upper Canada and is intended in part to fulfil the Law Society's articling requirements. At all times students on placement will be required to act in accordance with professional standards of practice. IPC skills components: file management, legal research, drafting, oral advocacy.

May only be taken by students in the 3rd year.

Courses.Title: Quantitative Methods Health Sc
Courses.Description:
An introduction to probability; the binomial, poisson and normal distributions; analysis of data; statistical inference; ANOVA; linear regression and correlation; nonparametric methods.

This course is not acceptable for credit in Mathematics or Computer Science programs. Students in other programs can receive credit for only one of the following courses or combinations of courses: Math 0210; Math 0212; Math 4030; Math 2310 and Math 2311; and Math 3332 and 3334.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 0212L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 0212 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Functions and Trigonometry
Courses.Description:
For students without grade 12 U Advanced Functions or equivalent. Cartesian coordinate systems; linear equations and straight lines; quadratic equations and parabolas; functions, including domain, range, graph, and composition of functions; angles and radian measure; the trigonometric functions, their graphs, and identities; the sine and cosine rules; polar coordinates; conic sections; and inequalities.

Students who have taken or are taking either Math 1151, Math 1171, or Math 1210 may not take this course for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1051L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1051 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Vectors and Matrices
Courses.Description:
For students without grade 12 U Calculus and Vectors or equivalent. Cartesian coordinates; vectors in two and three dimensions; the dot product and components of vectors; the cross product; equations of lines and planes; complex numbers; vector spaces over the real and complex number systems; linear independence, bases and spanning sets; subspaces; matrices; addition and scalar multiplication of matrices; matrix multiplication; the transpose of a matrix; invertible matrices; systems of linear equations and row reduction; and determinants, including Cramer's rule.

Students who have taken or are taking either Math 2255, Math 2070 or Math 2090 may not take this course for credit

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1071L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1071 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Sequences and Series
Courses.Description:
Exponents and logarithms and their algebra; geometric progressions; binomial coefficients and the binomial theorem; mathematical induction; sequences and their limits; the exponential and natural logarithm functions; infinite series; and tests for convergence of infinite series.

Students who have taken or are taking either Math 1151, Math 1171, or Math 1210 may not take this course for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1051 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1077L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1077 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Elementary Calculus
Courses.Description:
For students without Grade 12 U Calculus and Vectors or equivalent. Limits of functions and their properties; limits of exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions; indeterminate and infinite limits; continuity of functions; the definition of derivatives; equations of tangent lines; differentiation of the elementary functions; differentiation rules; applications of differential calculus including optimization, related rates, and curve sketching; anti-derivatives, the fundamental theorem of calculus, and area problems.

Students who have taken or are taking either Math 1171 or Math 1210 may not take this course for credit except if Mathematics 1078 is a required course for their academic program.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1077 needs to be either completed or registered for to take this course

Courses.Title: Calculus I Social & Life Sci
Courses.Description:
Functions, the derivative, logarithmic and exponential functions, the graphs of functions, applications of the derivative.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 1160 may not take Mathematics 1151 for credit. Students may only receive credit for one of: Math 1151, Math 1171, or Math 1210.

Courses.Title: Calculus II Social & Life Sci
Courses.Description:
Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, integration, applications of integration, and infinite series.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 1160 may not take Mathematics 1152 for credit. Students may only receive credit for one of: Math 1152, Math 1172, and Math 1230.

Courses.Title: Calculus I
Courses.Description:
Basic properties of the real number system; limits and continuity of functions; derivatives and differentiation formulas; applications of derivatives; anti-derivatives, definite integrals, indefinite integrals; Fundamental Theorem of Calculus; u-substitution.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 1180 may not take Mathematics 1171 for credit. Students may receive credit for only one of Math 1151, Math 1171, or Math 1210.

Courses.Title: Calculus II
Courses.Description:
Applications of integrals; one-to-one functions and inverses; logarithmic, exponential, power and inverse trigonometric functions; techniques of integration; limits of sequences; indeterminate forms; improper integrals; infinite series; tests for convergence; Taylor series; power series.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 1180 may not take Mathematics 1172 for credit. Students may only receive credit for one of: Math 1152, Math 1172, or Math 1230

Courses.Title: Calculus I for Engineers
Courses.Description:
Application of differentiation; definite and indefinite integrals; transcendental functions; complex numbers; techniques of integration.

Engineering students may substitute Mathematics 1171 for Mathematics 1210, with permission of the Dean of the Faculty of Engineering. Students may only receive credit for one of Math 1151, Math 1171, or Math 1210.

Courses.Title: Calculus II for Engineers
Courses.Description:
Applications of integration, introduction to multiple integrals sequences and series; power series.

Engineering students may substitute Mathematics 1172 for Mathematics 1230, with permission of the Dean of the Faculty of Engineering. Students may only receive credit for one of Math 1152, Math 1172, or Math 1230.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1210 needs to be completed to take this course

Courses.Title: Discrete Mathematics
Courses.Description:
Sets, logic, and functions; Boolean Algebras, Algorithms; Basic counting principles; permutations and combinations; discrete probability, recurrence relations; principle of inclusion and exclusion; pigeonhole principle; graph theory.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 1281 may not take Mathematics 1271/1272 for credit. Students may only receive credit for one of Math 1271 or Math 3071.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1271L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1271 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Logic, Set Theory, & Proofs
Courses.Description:
An introduction to proofs and to writing mathematics. Logic; propositional calculus; quantifiers, rules of inference, sets; set operations; cardinality and countability; relations, including partial orders and equivalence relations; functions; proof techniques such as direct proof; indirect proof; contradiction, and mathematical induction; basic properties of the integers.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 1281 may not take Mathematics 1271/1272 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1272L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1272 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Applied Analysis I
Courses.Description:
An introductory course in ordinary differential equations. First order differential equations; exact equations; separation of variables, integrating factors, linear and non-linear equations, higher order differential equations, linear, constant co-efficients, homogeneous, non-homogeneous. Systems of differential equations, Laplace transforms, series solution. The emphasis is on applications to engineering problems.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 3010 may not take Mathematics 2050 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1230 or 2030 need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 2050L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Recommended to be taken at the same time as this course, but is not required.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 2050 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Applied Analysis II
Courses.Description: The first part of the course is an introduction to matrix algebra. Solutions of simultaneous equations. Gaussian elimination. Vector and matrix notation. Determinants. Linear independence. Eigenvectors and diagonalization. The second part of the course is an introduction to probability and statistics. Simple ways of analyzing data. Concept of probability. Discrete and continuous probability. Point and interval estimation. Significance tests. Regression and correlation analysis.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 2070L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 2070 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Differential Equations
Courses.Description: Solutions of first order differential equations; applications. Solutions of second order linear differential equations with constant coefficients. Methods of finding particular solutions. Solutions of second order linear differential equations with variable coefficients. Applications.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take MATH-1152 or MATH-1172
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Vector Calculus
Courses.Description: Coordinate systems and vectors; parametric curves and surfaces; partial differentiation; multiple integration; vector fields; and vector calculus including Green's theorem, Stokes' theorem, and the divergence theorem.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take MATH-1172;     Minimum grade 50;
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Intro to Abstract Algebra
Courses.Description:
An introduction to groups, rings, and fields. Topics include properties of integers, subgroups, group homomorphisms, normal subgroups, factor groups, permutation groups, subrings, ring homomorphisms, ideals, and quotient rings.

Students who have previous credit in both Mathematics 2231 and 2233 may not take Mathematics 2232/2234 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Topics in Abstract Algebra
Courses.Description:
The properties of groups, rings, and fields are developed. Topics include polynomial rings, factorization, unique factorization domains, Euclidean domains, simple groups, Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian Groups. Additional topics may include field extensions, finite fields, geometric constructions, and the classification of groups of small order.

Students who have previous credit in both Mathematics 2231 and 2233 may not take Mathematics 2232/2234 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Math 2232 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Linear Algebra I
Courses.Description: Matrices and systems of linear equations; linear transformations and matrices; elementary matrix algebra; determinants; vector spaces; change of bases; real eigenvalues and eigenvectors; applications.

Courses.Title: Linear Algebra II
Courses.Description: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors; diagonalization; inner product spaces; orthogonal bases; least-squares problems; symmetric matrices; quadratic forms; singular value decomposition; applications.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Elementary Probability & Stats
Courses.Description:
Sample space and events, elementary probability. Descriptive statistics using tables and charts. Measures of central tendency, variability and association. Basic discrete and continuous distributions. Hypothesis testing and confidence intervals. Simple linear regression and correlation.

Not recognized as a mathematics credit for Mathematics majors. Students may only receive credit for one of the following courses or combinations of courses: Math 0210; Math 0212; Math 4030; Math 2310 and Math 2311; and Math 3332 and Math 3334.

CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Elementary Stat Methods
Courses.Description:
An introduction to statistical methods. Techniques include estimation, tests of hypothesis, analysis of variance and topics in experimental design. Students will also work with statistical software for data analysis.

Not recognized as a mathematics credit for Mathematics majors. Students may only receive credit for one of the following courses or combinations of courses: Math 0210; Math 0212; Math 4030; Math 2310 and Math 2311; and Math 3332 and Math 3334.

Courses.Title: Vector Analysis
Courses.Description:
Vectors, vector functions, and vector fields. Divergence, curl, and gradient in rectangular, cylindrical, and spherical co-ordinate systems. Line, surface, and multiple integrals. Theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 4012 may not take Mathematics 3012 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1230 or ENGI 3021 need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Complex Functions and PDEs
Courses.Description:
Power series and series solutions of differential equations. Power series solutions of Bessel's equation. Sturm-Liouville theorem and eigenfunctions. Linear partial differential equations (PDEs). Fourier Series in one and two variables. Fourier-Bessel solutions of boundary value problems. Complex functions and integrals. Cauchy's integral formula.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 4032 may not take Mathematics 3032 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 3012 and either MATH 2050 or 2090 need to be completed  to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Numerical Analysis & Computing
Courses.Description:
Error analysis, root finding; numerical integration; solution of linear equations; solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 4050 may not take Mathematics 3050 for credit.

Courses.Title: Discrete Math for Engineers
Courses.Description:
Basic set theory. Introduction to logic and proofs. Functions and relations. Mathematical induction and recursion. Algorithms; time estimates and orders of magnitude. Basic combinations. Graphs. Boolean algebras.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 4071 may not take Mathematics 3071 for credit. Students may only receive credit for one of Math 1271 or Math 3071.

Courses.Title: Partial Differential Eq I
Courses.Description:
A study of partial differential equations (e.g. diffusion, wave, potential); boundary value problems; Sturm-Liouville problems; Fourier series; special functions.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 3131 may not take Mathematics 3111 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: # TAKE MATH-2111 MATH-2131; MINIMUM GRADE 50;
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Partial Differential Eq II
Courses.Description:
A study of partial differential equations in polar, cylindrical and spherical co-ordinates; special functions; non-homogeneous problems; Fourier and other transform techniques.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 3133 may not take Mathematics 3113 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: # TAKE MATH-3111; MINIMUM GRADE 50;
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Methods Math Physics I
Courses.Description:
A study of partial differential equations (e.g. diffusion, wave, potential); boundary value problems; Sturm-Liouville problems; Fourier series; special functions.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 3111 may not take Mathematics 3131 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Methods Math Physics II
Courses.Description:
A study of partial differential equations in polar, cylindrical and spherical co-ordinates; special functions; non-homogeneous problems; Fourier and other transform techniques.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 3113 may not take Mathematics 3133 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Complex Analysis
Courses.Description: The geometry of the complex plane, analytic functions, Moebius transformations, the Cauchy-Goursat theorem, power series, the residue theorem, conformal mapping.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 3231 and 3233 or 2131 need to be completed to take  this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Introductory Analysis I
Courses.Description: Review of logic and set theory; properties of the real numbers; order completeness of the reals; metric space topology including completeness, compactness, and connectedness; numerical sequences and series.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Must have MATH-1172 and MATH-1272 to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Introductory Analysis II
Courses.Description: Limits of functions, continuity, the derivative of a real function, the mean value theorems, l'Hospital's rule, Taylor's theorem, the Riemann integral, sequences and series of functions, uniform and pointwise convergence, and power series.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Intro Math Probability
Courses.Description:
A mathematical introduction to the theory and application of probability. Topics may include distributions and their properties, limit theorems, expectation and simulations.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 2331 may not take Mathematics 3332 for credit. Students may only receive credit for one of the following courses or combination of courses: Math 0210; Math 0212; Math 4030; Math 2310 and Math 2311; and Math 3332 and Math 3334.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 1172 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 3332 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Intro Math Statistics
Courses.Description:
A mathematical introduction to statistics, using the probability theory developed in Mathematics 3332. Topics include point and interval estimation, test of hypothesis, non-parametric methods, goodness of fit, experimental design, analysis of variance and covariance, regression and correlation.

Students who have previous credit in Mathematics 2333 may not take Mathematics 3334 for credit. Students may only receive credit for one of the following courses or combinations or courses: Math 0210; Math 0212; Math 4030; Math 2310 and Math 2311; and Math 3332 and Math 3334.

CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Applied Numerical Methods
Courses.Description: An introduction to various numerical techniques for such tasks as approximating integrals, solving systems of equations, solving ordinary and partial differential equations, finding roots of equations in one variable and approximating functions.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 2111 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 3351L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 3351 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Combinatorics & Graph Theory
Courses.Description: Review of primes and basic number theory, binomial coefficients and other special number sequences, generating functions, graphs, trees, paths and connectivity, matchings, colourings, flows, and algorithms in combinatorics and graph theory.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Must have MATH-1271 to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Probability & Statistics
Courses.Description:
Probability and relative frequency; joint probabilities of related and independent events; Bayes' Theorem; statistical independence; random variables; cumulative distribution functions; probability density functions; parameters describing the central tendency and dispersion of distribution; probability distribution functions in engineering; law of large numbers; central limit theorem; testing hypotheses and goodness of fit; sampling theory; linear correlation and regression.

Students may only receive credit for one of the following courses or combinations of courses: Math 0210; Math 0212; Math 4030; Math 2310 and Math 2311; and Math 3332 and Math 3334.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 2070 or ENGI 3021 need to be completed to take this  course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Advanced Calculus
Courses.Description: Topology of Rn. Continuity and differentiability of functions from Rn to Rm. Taylor's Theorem for functions of n variables. Maxima and minima; positive definite and negative definite quadratic forms. The Inverse Function Theorem and the Implicit Function Theorem. Fubini's Theorem. Change of variables in multiple integrals.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Honours Seminar
Courses.Description: Required of honours mathematics majors in their fourth year. Normally consists of seminars presented by the staff and students, who are asked to prepare and present a number of papers.

Courses.Title: Intro to Popular Culture
Courses.Description:
For full course description, see course description for English 1117.

Students who have previous credit in English 2902 may not take English/Media, Film, and Communications 1117 for credit.

Courses.Title: Intro to Film Studies
Courses.Description:
For full course description, see course description for English 1118.

Courses.Description: For full course description, please see course description for English 3952.

CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Music Appreciation
Courses.Description:
A survey of Western Art Music and its connection to today's popular music. Special emphasis will be placed on the development of critical listening skills. 

No Formal background in Music required

Courses.Title: Rudiments of Music
Courses.Description: An introduction to rudiments of music, including note values, time signatures, scales, chords, musical terms, elementary harmony and transposition.

Courses.Title: Musicianship I
Courses.Description: The fundamentals of musicianship through studies in rhythmic, melodic and harmonic ear training, sight singing, and melodic, rhythmic and harmonic dictation.

Courses.Title: Wind Ensemble I
Courses.Description:
Designed to provide performing experience in small groups.

Open to non-Music majors by permission of the Chair of the Department

Courses.Title: Vocal Ensemble I
Courses.Description:
Designed to provide performing experience in a large group and to familiarize students with choral repertoire.

Open to non-Music majors by permission of the Department

Courses.Title: Theory I
Courses.Description: A survey of elementary theoretical applications related to tonal and modal systems. Topics include the study of music rudiments, introduction to diatonic harmony, tonal harmonic progressions, and cadences.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MUSI-1310 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Theory II
Courses.Description: An exploration of the evolution of theoretical concepts related to various music time periods. Topics include diatonic harmonic part writing and analysis, keyboard and chorale style harmony, elementary counterpoint and the study of small forms.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MUSI-1350 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Music History IV
Courses.Description: Continuing the study of the history of Western music, concentrating on the music of the Modern Era. Topics include impressionism, expressionism, dodecaphony, indeterminacy, analog and digital sound synthesis, and minimalism.

Courses.Description: An examination of the emergence of chromaticism as an extension of diatonic harmony. Topics include the study of chromatic four-part harmony, extended chord application, altered, borrowed, Neapolitan, and augmented 6th chords.

Courses.Description: An examination of 16th and 18th century contrapuntal practices, classical and romantic musical forms, twentieth-century music styles, and the analysis of contemporary musical forms.

Courses.Description:
A study of Canadian music, musicians, and musical life from colonial times to the present day. Emphasis will be placed on musical composition in Canada after 1918.

Open to non-Music majors by permission of the Department

Courses.Description:
Portfolio of completed compositions is required at the end of the year.

Enrolment is restricted to Music majors.  Students taking this course may not enroll in Music 4304.

Courses.Title: Piano Pedagogy & Teach Tech
Courses.Description:
Teaching methods and materials for beginning, intermediate and advanced students. Topics include repertoire selection, technical development, practice strategies, interpretation and analysis, history of piano pedagogy and current pedagogical theory, recognition and avoidance of physical injuries, overcoming performance anxiety, memorization, and performance preparation. 

Open to students in the Artist Certificate in Performance and Pedagogy, HBMus or HBA (Music), or by permission of the instructor

Courses.Description:

Courses.Description: A directed study which will result in an original research paper of musicological significance. This course is designed for students considering graduate study in historical musicology, ethnomusicology, or related fields.
