CourseRequisites.DisplayText: OUTD 4611 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Outdoor Rec & Tourism Planning
Courses.Description: An advanced examination of theories, issues, and practices of nature-based tourism planning and development. Includes team-based project development, research, and reporting in response to local and regional industry partners' needs. Site visits may be required.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Outdoor Recreation 2210 and 2755 need to be completed to  take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Ethics & Justice in Travel
Courses.Description: A critical analysis of tourism and recreation using theories of and approaches to ethics. Addresses current issues in tourism and recreation, including sustainable and responsible tourism, social and environmental justice, human rights, and legal responsibilities. Students will advance their understanding of the relevance and application of moral principles and philosophy within the context of personal and professional ethical development.

Courses.Title: Coastal & Marine Protect Areas
Courses.Description: An examination of freshwater and marine protected areas and their use for recreation and tourism. Local and international case studies will examine the complex ecological, social, and political dimensions of sustainably managing aquatic environments.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Outdoor Recreation 2210 and 2755 need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Standards Practice Therapeutic
Courses.Description: Students will examine and implement the phases of delivering therapeutic recreation programming. Assessment, evidence based program design, and evaluation of nature based experiences for a variety of populations will be explored theoretically and experientially.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Outdoor Recreation 3610 needs to be completed to take this  course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Career Explorations in ORPT
Courses.Description:
Students develop their professional competencies and job readiness by exploring theory, principles, and best practices within ORPT professional spheres.  Opportunities for job shadowing and/or short placements represent opportunities for experiential learning in a field of interest.

Students who have previous credit in Outdoor Recreation 4920 may not take Outdoor Recreation 4912 for credit.  It may only be taken by 4th year Honours Bachelor of Outdoor Recreation students.

Courses.Title: Intro to Philosophy: Origins
Courses.Description: Examination of the history of philosophy, from the pre-Socratics to the Modern era of philosophy. Philosophers discussed may include Thales, Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, St. Augustine, and Thomas Aquinas.

Courses.Title: Intro Philosophy: Modern Devel
Courses.Description: Examination of the history of philosophy, from Descartes to twentieth century thinkers. Philosophers discussed may include Descartes, Locke, Hume, Kant, Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche, Russell, Marcuse, and Baudrillard.

Courses.Title: Contemporary Moral Issues
Courses.Description: Clarification of moral issues such as war, capital punishment, suicide, euthanasia, abortion and poverty. Evaluation of arguments on both sides of the issues. Moral theories and their relation to moral decisions.

Courses.Title: Logic
Courses.Description: An introduction to formal logic from the categorical logic of Aristotle to the first order predicate calculus with emphasis on the problems in translating natural language expressions into symbolic form.

Courses.Title: Business Ethics
Courses.Description: Ethical problems in business: business and social justice, property rights, wages and profits, the individual in the corporation and the corporation as moral agent. Emphasis is on responsibilities of those in business to shareholders, employers, employees, customers and the environment.

Courses.Title: Science and Technology
Courses.Description: An examination of the relationship between science and technology, and, by extension, of theory to practice; the questions whether there are kinds of knowledge, and whether science is the pre-eminent kind; the distinction, if any, between science and non-science or pseudo- or proto-science.

Courses.Title: Death
Courses.Description: It has been called, along with taxes, the one certainty in life, the thing that all of us fear, the great leveller. Cicero claimed that to learn to die is the aim of philosophy. This view, and others concerning the nature and import of death and dying, will be examined.

Courses.Title: Philosophy of Law
Courses.Description: The fundamentals of law and legal systems: the relation of law to morality and justice, the nature of law, kinds of law and the justifications for different systems of law, the function of law within the nation-state and internationally. Emphasis is on legal theory with some case studies in law.

Courses.Title: Kant & the Nineteenth Century
Courses.Description:
An examination of 19th century philosophical developments as proceeding from and in opposition to Kant. Movements and figures studied include German idealism (Fichte, Schelling, Hegel, Schopenhauer), neo-Kantianism (Feuerbach), early positivism (Comte), Marxism, early pragmatism (Pierce), Utilitarianism (Bentham, Mill), early existentialism (Kierkegaard, Nietzsche), and Transcendentalism (Emerson, Thoreau).

Students who have previous credit in Philosophy 2615 may not take Philosophy 3615 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHIL 2614 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Philosophy of Mind
Courses.Description: The principal theories in modern philosophy concerning the nature of the mind, such as dualism, materialism, behaviorism, psycho-analysis, artificial intelligence.

Courses.Title: Philosophy of Religion
Courses.Description: Philosophical examination of issues such as the definition of religion and religious cults, the existence of God, the problems of sin and evil, personal immortality, religious experience, and mysticism, religious language and the problem of religious pluralism.

Courses.Title: Senior Seminar
Courses.Description: Topics in the history of philosophy decided annually, based on faculty and student interests. For details, consult the Chair.

Courses.Title: Intr App Phys II (Electricit)
Courses.Description:
This is a non-calculus introduction to electricity, magnetism, optics and modern physics.

Course designated for Common Year in Applied Science students.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1010L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1010 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Intro Appl Phys I (Mechanics)
Courses.Description:
This is a non-calculus introduction to kinematics, Newton's Laws, energy, and waves.

Course designated for Common Year in Applied Science students.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1030L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1030 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Semiconductor Physics
Courses.Description: Physics of semiconductors including crystal structure, conductivity, photoelectric effect, Hall effect, atomic energy levels and band theory, Fermi-Dirac statistics and density of states, intrinsic and extrinsic properties. The physics of common semiconductor devices are also discussed.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1070L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Physics Essentials I
Courses.Description:
A non-calculus course primarily designed for students who wish a broad overview of basic physical principles and concepts, but do not require the calculus-based analysis needed for further study. Topics include: motion in one and two dimensions; Newton's Laws; work and energy; momentum and collisions; oscillations; rotational motion; gravitation; elasticity and fluids; waves and sound. Laboratory work is mandatory.

Students may receive credit for only one of Physics 1010/1030, 1101, 1113/1133.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1113L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1113 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Physics Essentials II
Courses.Description:
This is a continuation of the basic principles approach started in Physics 1113. Topics include: electric forces, fields, and potential energy; capacitance, resistance, and DC circuits; magnetism and AC circuits; special relativity; optics; atomic and nuclear physics. Laboratory work is mandatory.

Students may receive credit for only one of Physics 1010/1030, 1101, 1113/1133.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1113 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1133L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1133 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Introductory Physics I
Courses.Description:
A calculus-based course intended for students in the physical sciences, applied sciences and mathematics, which includes the study of Newtonian mechanics for particles and rigid bodies, accompanied by related laboratory work.

Students may receive credit for only one of Physics 1030, 1101, 1211, 1113.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1211L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1211 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Introductory Physics II
Courses.Description:
A calculus-based course intended for students in the physical sciences and applied sciences which includes Oscillations, mechanical waves and sound, electric charge, electric field. Coulomb's law, Gauss's law, applications of Gauss's law, electric potential, capacitance, dielectrics, current, resistance, direct current circuit, magnetic field, electromagnetic induction, alternating current, electromagnetic waves and wave properties of light, accompanied by related laboratory work.

Students may receive credit for only one of Physics 1010, 1101, 1212, 1133.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1211 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1212L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1212 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Classical Mechanics I
Courses.Description: Covers dimensional analysis, generalized coordinates, conserved quantities, linear oscillators including dissipation and resonance, small vibrations, oscillator chains and normal modes, central forces and the Kepler problem, and rigid bodies including rotating coordinate systems and the inertia tensor.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: You must have PHYS-1211 completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take MATH-2111
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Intermediate Electricity & Mag
Courses.Description: Direct and alternating circuit theory is introduced with specific attention to Kirchhoff's laws, Thevenin's theorem, phasor notation (complex numbers), and transient analysis. This forms the theoretical basis of the laboratory part of the course. Electrostatics covers Coulomb's law, Gauss' flux theorem and the definition of the electric potential with an emphasis on vector and scalar fields. Electrostatic theory is applied to capacitors and dielectric materials. Magnetostatics covers calculations of the magnetic field and the Lorentz force using the Biot-Savart law and Ampere's circuital law. Finally, electrodynamics covers Faraday's law of induction with applications in mutual and self-inductance. This course requires a strong background in mathematics and some vector calculus.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS-1212 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: MATH 2131 and PHYS 2211L need to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 2211 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Introduction to Optics
Courses.Description: Geometrical optics; reflection and refraction, thin lenses, thick lenses, aberrations, optical instruments. Physical optics. Huygen's principle, interference and diffraction, resolving power, polarization.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1212 or PHYS 1113/1133 need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 2311L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 2311 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Modern Physics I
Courses.Description: Relativity, the photon, the wave-particle aspects of electromagnetic radiation and matter; introduction to wave mechanics; the hydrogen atom and atomic line spectra; orbital and spin angular momenta.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 1212 or PHYS 1113/1133 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Intro to Medical Physics
Courses.Description:
Applications of physics in medicine. The course content will address concepts of medical physics, the production and properties of x-rays, photon and charge particle interaction with matter, diagnostic radiation medical imaging, nuclear medicine and radiation isotopes, and radiation therapy.

Normally offered in alternating years.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: You must have PHYS 1211 and 1212, or PHYS 1133 completed to  take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Quantum Info & Quantum Comput
Courses.Description: Introduces the qubit as the basic element of quantum information, and its use in quantum information processing.  It also includes an introduction to the formalism of quantum mechanics, elementary manipulations of qubits, and basic algorithm such as Grover's iteration, quantum error correction, and some simple protocols with a few qubits.

Courses.Title: Quantum Mechanics I
Courses.Description: Classical causality, Heinsenberg's principle, position and momentum determining experiments, wave packets and spread, electromagnetism, wave-particle duality, de Broglie particle-wave duality, matter waves, electron stability, Schr?dinger equation, boundary conditions, finite and infinite one-dimensional wells. Transmission and reflection coefficients. Introduction to simple harmonic oscillator and the hydrogen atom. Emphasis will be on applications of interest to physicists and chemists.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Electromagnetic Theory
Courses.Description: Topics covered include vector operators, electrostatic potential andforce, magnetostatics, Faraday's law of induction, laws relating changing electric and magnetic fields, Maxwell's equations in integral and differential form, boundary conditions, electromagnetic radiation and energy propagation, Fresnel's equations, and basic antenna theory.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 2211 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 3211L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 3211 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Introductory Electronics
Courses.Description: The course begins with a rapid review of DC and AC circuit theory. Basic bipolar junction transistor circuits are then covered; such as the emitter follower, current sources and mirrors, the common emitter, push-pull, and differential amplifiers. A number of linear and non-linear operational amplifier circuits are examined with an emphasis on negative and positive feedback circuit analysis. Specialized amplifiers used as comparators, triggers, and oscillators are also examined. A quick overview of the field effect transistor, amplifier noise, and filter bandwidth rounds out the course. This is a laboratory intensive course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 2211 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 3231L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 3231 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Fibre Optic Communications
Courses.Description: Basic fibre theory: types, modes, losses, dispersion, nonlinearities. Passive fibre devices: couplers, connectors, splices. Light sources: LED, solid state and semiconductor lasers. Active devices: modulators, amplifiers, and detectors. System noise: noise sources, eye diagrams, and bit error rate analysis. System design and local area networks.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 3311L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 3311 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Condensed Matter Physics
Courses.Description:
Provides an understanding of condensed matter physics with an emphasis on the electronic structure of solids. Topics covered include the structure and binding of solids, reciprocal lattice and diffraction, free electron Fermi gas, band theory of metals and semiconductors, and magnetism.

Normally offered in alternating years.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Quantum Mechanics II
Courses.Description: The course will include the following topics: Free particles and Fourier series, Dirac delta-function, vector spaces, axioms, Hermitian operators, uncertainty principle, destruction and creation operators for harmonic oscillators, angular momentum in three dimensions, ladder operators, central potentials, hydrogen atom, spin and the exclusion principle, stationary and time dependent perturbation theory.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Statistical Mechanics & Therma
Courses.Description:
Integrated treatment of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics, review of elementary probability theory, canonical distribution and partition function, grand canonical ensemble, free energy, introduction to ideal quantum gases, and application to astrophysics and low-temperature physics.

Normally offered in alternating years.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PHYS 2151 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Electromagnetics
Courses.Description: Maxwell's equations, Fresnel's equations, the equation of continuity and Poynting vector applications are reviewed. Scalar and vector potentials, the gauge transformation, and the inhomogeneous wave equation are discussed. Retarded potentials with applications to dipole radiation, the half-wave antenna, directed arrays and the diffraction grating are introduced. Wave guide and transmission line theory are discussed. Lienard-Wiechert potentials are introduced and applied to radiation from an accelerated charge.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Adv Experimental Physics I
Courses.Description: The experiments will be based on fourth year physics courses. Topics considered will include several of the following: x-ray diffraction and crystal structure determination, investigation of laser types and applications, and the use of dispersive and interferometric optical spectrometers.

Courses.Title: Adv Experimental Physics II
Courses.Description: Experiments demonstrating the fundamental physical principles underlying radiation and ultrasound medical imaging (photoconductivity, pulse-height spectroscopy and ultrasound propagation through matter) as well as experiments with clinical systems (digital direct conversion x-ray detector, Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scanner and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)).

Courses.Title: Res Topic Studs Physics
Courses.Description: A research project, chosen in consultation with a faculty advisor, will be conducted under the supervision of that advisor. The student will prepare a thesis and present a Physics Department seminar.

Courses.Title: Intro Political Sci
Courses.Description: An introduction to the scope, concepts and methods of Political Science, including the institutional and social framework of political activity illustrated by reference to Canada and other political systems, and to the role of political ideas.

Courses.Title: Introduction to Law
Courses.Description: Introduces fundamental legal concepts and legal systems. Examines the types of law, the process of lawmaking, the organization of the legal system, the role of law in various political systems, and other primary issues related to the study and practice of law. Examples are drawn from Canadian and other legal systems of the world. Uses a variety of robust experiential components designed to prepare students for subsequent courses in law and politics.

Courses.Title: Cdn Government & Politics
Courses.Description:
Examines the development and practice of Canadian political institutions, especially the Prime Minister, Parliament, and the Courts. Also covers the interaction between the executive and the legislature, the role of interest groups and political parties in policy making, and the legal and political impact of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

Students who have received previous credit in Political Science 2201, 2212 or 2213 may not take Political Science 2110 for credit. Open only to students in their second year level or higher.

Courses.Title: Criminal Law
Courses.Description: A study of the Canadian Criminal Code, rules of evidence, and sentencing. The course will draw on recent court decisions and procedures.

Courses.Title: Human Rights & Civil Liberties
Courses.Description: The study of human rights with emphasis on Canadian civil liberties, the Bill of Rights and constitutional developments. The course will also examine civil liberties, human rights and minority group protection in an international context.

Courses.Title: Ancient & Medieval Pol Thought
Courses.Description:
The contribution of Classical and Medieval thinkers to the development of ideas about political practice in the West will be studied. The primary goal is to acquaint the student with the variety of opinion around such subjects as community, society, law and justice, and power. Students will also be encouraged to challenge the assumptions of these thinkers with regard to a wide variety of "modern" political perspectives such as technology and media, gender, and post-modernism.

Students who have previous credit in Political Science 2520 may not take Political Science 2510 for credit.

Courses.Title: World Politics
Courses.Description: A study of the changing structure of world politics with reference to theories, concepts, and case studies in international relations.

Courses.Title: Law and Politics of the Family
Courses.Description:
A survey of family law in Canada including the political issues and controversies.

Students who have previous credit in Political Science 2315 may not take Political Science 3113 for credit.

Courses.Title: Global Terrorism
Courses.Description: The global trends in terrorism and the specific controversies relating to the definition of terrorism will be examined. Students will comparatively analyze the various types of terrorism, both past and present, and explore the future patterns and potentialities of terrorism, in order to prepare recommendations for facing international terrorism. In this manner, students will develop a clear understanding of the extraordinarily complex world of terrorism.

Courses.Title: Law & Pol: Special Topics
Courses.Description:
An examination of a selected topic in law and politics. Issues to be examined will vary according to the interests of the students and the instructor. May be taken more than twice provided that the special topics are different.

Open only to students in their second year level or higher.

Courses.Title: International Peacebuilding
Courses.Description: Examines traditional peacebuilding approaches used by international actors including conflict management, conflict resolution, hybrid, and everyday local peacebuilding processes. Nation-state international relations processes will be contrasted with people's agency to transform and resolve conflicts at the regional, national, and local levels. Peacebuilding methods to be studied include reconciliation and forgiveness, truth commissions, restorative and transitional justice, diplomacy and negotiation, external economic aid, social justice, Indigenous peacebuilding, and spatial transformation. The course is structured as a seminar and envisioned as a collective exercise in critical thinking and practice.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: 1 FCE in Political Science needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Honours Thesis Preparation
Courses.Description: Preparation for the writing of a full thesis for which adequate supervision is available within the department. The subject will be chosen in conjunction with the department and one or more member(s) of the department will be appointed supervisor(s). Tasks include a thesis proposal, literature review, and thesis chapter.

Courses.Title: Honours Thesis
Courses.Description: The production of a full thesis. Furthers work begun in Political Science 4111. The subject will be chosen in conjunction with the department, and one or more member(s) of the department will be appointed supervisor(s). Dependent on faculty availability.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Political Science 4111 needs to be completed with a  minimum grade ot 75% to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Topics in Constitutional Law
Courses.Description: An examination of selected key contemporary issues in the areas of Law and Legal Studies. Issues to be examined will vary according to the interests of the students and the instructor.

Courses.Title: Global Political Economy
Courses.Description: An examination of theoretical and practical issues in global political economy. Topics include: theories of international political economy, economic reforms, multinational corporations, technology transfer, economic development and cultural change, patterns of trade and trade blocs, environmentalism, the external debt crisis of developing countries and the economic stabilization programs supported by the International Monetary Fund.

Courses.Title: Introductory Psychology
Courses.Description: This introductory course is designed to provide an appreciation of the scope of psychology and its sub-specialities, to render an understanding of the research-based methods which are fundamental to all aspects of the discipline, to provide an awareness of the biopsychosocial bases of behaviour and to lay the groundwork for further study in psychology.

Courses.Title: Child Development
Courses.Description:
Examination of child development from conception through adolescence with a focus on theory and research on biological, social, personality, and cognitive development.

Students not yet in second year who have obtained credit in Psychology 1100 may request permission to register in this course. Students who have previous credit in Psychology 2002 may not take Psychology 2011/3012 for credit.

Courses.Title: Foundations of Neuroscience
Courses.Description:
Behavioural neuroscience examines the properties of the brain, the peripheral nervous system, and the endocrine system, and examines the integration of these systems to produce our perceptions, cognitions, and controlled motor behaviours. Provides foundational knowledge of neuroscience, including the organ, cellular, and biochemical processes involved with behaviour. Topics will include an introduction to brain anatomy, cytology, neurophysiology, genetics, and neuroendocrinology. 

Students who have previous credit in Psychology 2401 may not take Psychology 2013/3013 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 1100 or 1 FCE Type C courses needs to be completed to  take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Foundations of Cognition 1
Courses.Description:
Cognitive Psychology is used throughout the entire range of human knowledge, perception, activity, speech processing, problem solving, learning, and memory. Provides students knowledge of the basic processes in, and neuroscience associated with, human cognition, including perception, learning, attention, working memory, and semantic, episodic, and procedural memory foundations of long-term memory.

Students who have previous credit in Psychology 2003 may not take Psychology 2014/3014 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 1100 of 1 FCE Type C courses needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Social Psychology
Courses.Description:
Review of theories, methods, and research in the scientific study of how a person's thoughts, feelings, and behaviours are influenced by the social situation. Topics will include social cognition, social perception, attitudes, and group processes. Applications to interpersonal relationships, prejudice, and discrimination will be covered.

Students not yet in second year who have obtained credit in Psychology 1100 may request permission to register in this course.  Students who have previous credit in Psychology 2801 may not take Psychology 2015 for credit.

Courses.Title: Adult Development
Courses.Description:
Review of theories, methods, and research in the scientific study of how a person's thoughts, feelings, and behaviours are influenced by the social situation. Topics will include social cognition, social perception, attitudes, and group processes. Applications to interpersonal relationships, prejudice, and discrimination will be covered.

Students not yet in second year who have obtained credit in Psychology 1100 may request permission to register in this course.  Students who have previous credit in Psychology 2801 may not take Psychology 2015 for credit.

Courses.Title: Research Methods in Psychology
Courses.Description:
Examines the theoretical and practical aspects of conducting research in the behavioural sciences. Topics will include: searching for a worthwhile research problem, examining and evaluating different types of research designs, research ethics, planning and conducting research, issues in data analysis, and interpreting and communicating research findings.

Students with previous credit in Psychology 3911 may not take Psychology 2110 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 1100 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 2110L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC-2110 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Statistics for Psychology 1
Courses.Description:
This is a gentle introduction to basic statistics-yes, math-that you should be able to handle if you know how to use a calculator. You will learn what probability really means and how we use it, our logical thinking, and mathematical procedures to test ideas in Psychology.

Students who have previous credit in Psychology 2101 may not take Psychology 2112 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 1100 and 2110 need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC-2112L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 2112 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Learning
Courses.Description:
A review of the foundations of conditioning and learning in physiology and behaviourist psychology but updates these earlier approaches with the view that learning is an evolved biological mechanism and that what is learned is limited by biological constraints. Content includes coverage of classical and operant conditioning, observational learning, the limits of learning, and the complementary roles of biology and the environment on what is and can be learned.

Students not yet in second year who have obtained credit in Psychology 1100 may request permission to register in this course.

Courses.Title: Behavioural Neuroscience
Courses.Description:
Builds upon foundational knowledge of neuroscience by providing an overview of key behavioral neuroscience topics including behavioral endocrinology/sexual development, sensory neuroscience, psychomotoric systems, sleep physiology, physiology of learning and memory, and biology of mood disorders.

Students with previous credit in Psychology 2401 may not take Psychology 2013/3013 for credit

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 2013 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Foundations of Cognition 2
Courses.Description:
Introduces the concepts, and experimental research of, language, reasoning, decision-making, problem solving, and affective behaviour. Deals with the study of both general psychological processes and neuropsychological specialization as well as deficits within each of these areas.

Students who have previous credit in Psychology 2003 may not take Psychology 2014/3014 for credit

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 2014 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Psychometric Theory
Courses.Description:
Examines theories and principles underlying the construction and evaluation of psychological tests. Topics will include the history of measurement and psychological tests, relevant statistical procedures, norms and transformations, reliability, validity, and test construction. 

Students with previous credit in Psychology 3201 may not take this course for credit

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 2110 and 2112 need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC- 3015L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC-3015 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Personality Psychology
Courses.Description:
Examines topics in traditional and contemporary personality psychology. Focuses on personality assessment, motivation, biological and genetic influences, sex and gender, traits, the self-concept, and the evolutionary function of personality. Additionally, the association between personality and relationships, health outcomes, morality, and beliefs will be covered.

Students with previous credit in Psychology 2301 may not obtain credit in Psychology 3016.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC-1100 and 0,5 FCE in Psychology need to be completed to  take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Foundations of Mental Health
Courses.Description:
Critically examines concepts related to the understanding of mental health (including mental wellness and mental illness). Focuses on a multidimensional understanding of mental health and examines the factors which influence our conceptualizations: historical, biological, psychological, interpersonal, cultural, and political. Provides a foundation for understanding mental health and mental illness.  

Students not yet in second year who have obtained credit in Psychology 1100 may request permission to register in this course.  Students with previous credit in Psychology 2004 may not take Psychology 3017 for credit

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: 1 FCE in Psychology needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Sensory Neurosci Fundamentals
Courses.Description:
Introduces the study of our senses beginning with understanding the environmental stimulus, energy transduction, and the early stages of signal processing. Emphasis will be placed on examining the underlying neural mechanisms of sensory processing that will include an introduction to neurophysiology and psychophysical measurement. Many of the visual neuroscience principles discussed earlier in the term will be applied to one or more of the following modalities: audition, somesthesis, and taste/olfaction.

Students with previous credit in Psychology 3161 may not take Psychology 3019/4019 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC-1100 or 1 FCE from Type C coruses needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Statistics for Psychology 2
Courses.Description:
Advanced statistics builds upon the basic fund of statistical knowledge and numeracy skills. Focuses on testing hypotheses in Psychology by combining the explanatory power of multiple variables.

Students in the Specialized Honours program must take this course before their thesis year. Students with previous credit in Psychology 2101 may not take this course for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 2110 and 2112 need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC-3112L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC-3112 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Principles Psychopharmacology
Courses.Description:
An introduction to psychopharmacology focusing on key principles related to pharmacokinetics (e.g., routes of drug administration, drug metabolism), pharmacodynamics (e.g., neurotransmitters systems), tolerance, withdrawal, and addiction. Research methods and paradigms in the field are discussed and principles are illustrated with psychoactive drugs such as alcohol.

Students with previous credit in Psychology 3401 may not take Psychology 3114/3115 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC-1100 and 0.5 FCE in Psychology need to be completed to  take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Psychology of Human Sexuality
Courses.Description: A multi-disciplinary examination of the complex issues involved in human sexuality. Topics will include anatomy, physiology, ethics, unconventional sexuality, aging, and identification and treatment of sexual disorders.

Courses.Title: Special Topics in Psychology
Courses.Description: This course will cover a specific topic in Psychology. The topic may vary from year to year and will be announced in advance by the Department.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC-1100 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Indigenous Mental Health
Courses.Description: An in-depth exploration of mental health and addiction among Indigenous Peoples in Canada.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: 3 FCEs in Psychology need to be completed to take this  course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Perception & Perceptual Proces
Courses.Description:
Higher-ordered visual and auditory processes such as colour, form, movement, depth, loudness, pitch, and speech perception as well as mechanisms of attention will be investigated. Some clinical dysregulations and pathologies that help illuminate understanding of key processing pathways will also be explored.

Students with previous credit in Psychology 3161 may not take Psychology 3019/4019 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC-3019 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Adv Seminar in Psychotherapy
Courses.Description:
An advanced, critical analysis of contemporary psychotherapeutic modalities and their underlying theoretical and empirical bases, process of change, and empirical evidence on their efficacy. Their limitations will also be discussed. Suited to students interested in graduate studies in clinical or counselling psychology. Selection of specific topics may vary from year to year.

Students who have previous credit in Psychology 4020 may not take Psychology 4033 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: 3 FCEs in Psychology need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Statistics for Psychology 3
Courses.Description: For the aspiring researcher in Psychology, newer and specialized statistical procedures will be the focus. Prepares students to plan, analyze, and interpret the results of their honours thesis.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 3112 and 2.5 FCEs in Psychology need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 4111L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 4111 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Human Memory
Courses.Description: Neurological, information processing, and cognitive perspectives on human learning and memory. The topics include acquisition, storage, and retrieval of memory, the durability of memory, the development of specific skills, everyday/applied memory, and disorders of memory.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Three FCEs in Psychology need to be completed to take this  course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Emotion and Motivation
Courses.Description: Neurophysiological, evolutionary, information processing, and cognitive/affective perspectives on human emotion, motivation and the interaction of human emotion and cognition. The topics include emotion as behaviour, communication, and representation and descriptions of the physiological and affective contributions to motivated behaviour and decisions.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: 3 FCEs in Psychology need to be completed to take this  course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: History of Psychology
Courses.Description: The historical and theoretical foundations of psychology from its philosophical and scientific antecedents to the early studies of the nervous system will be reviewed. Main currents in psychological thought such as the emergence of experimental psychology and the development of clinical psychology will be emphasized.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: 3 FCEs in Psychology need to be completed to take this  course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Honours Thesis
Courses.Description:
Intended for students planning to pursue graduate studies. This capstone experience provides students with the opportunity to integrate their learning and to demonstrate the knowledge and skills they have gained throughout their studies in Psychology. Students will work with a faculty supervisor to engage in all stages of the research process, from conceptualization to communication of findings. 

Registration is by special permission only. Students must apply to the Department of Psychology by November of the year before their thesis year (normally the third year). Contact the Department of Psychology for more information.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 3112 and 3015 need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: PSYC 4111 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Introduction to Sociology
Courses.Description: Sociological exploration of society, culture, social interaction and power relations. Topics may include (but not limited to): crime, economy, education, environment, gender, globalization, health and society, racial and class inequality, urbanization.

Courses.Title: Environmental Sociology
Courses.Description: Introduction to the major theoretical perspectives in environmental sociology, learning to apply them to a variety of contemporary environmental issues.

Courses.Title: Sociology of Health & Illness
Courses.Description:
A study of the social and cultural dimensions of health and illness. Topics may include: the social organization of medicine; social determinants of health status; lay perspectives on health, illness and the body; the experience of illness and health care; and the impact of social change on medical beliefs and practice.

Students who have previous credit in Sociology 3509/Gerontology 3509 may not take Sociology 2509/Gerontology 2509 for credit.

Courses.Title: Tech Soc Indi People Can
Courses.Description: Examines the relationships between science, technology, social institutions and culture, with a focus on how these issues impact Canada's Indigenous Peoples.

Courses.Title: Foundation Sociological Res
Courses.Description:
A focus on the skills and knowledge required to carry out sociological research including the meaning of methodology, research design, the purpose and structure of a literature review, measurement, sampling procedures, survey design, and field research/ethics.

A required course for Sociology majors.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: SOCI 1100 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Life Course Studies
Courses.Description: A critical examination of aging across the life course, from childhood to old age, with a focus on the interplay of agency and structure in shaping outcomes.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take SOCI 1100 or GERO 1110 and GERO 1130 or SOWK 1100
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Special Topics
Courses.Description: The topic of this course will vary according to the interests and availability of instructors.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Requisite with no print text exists
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Quantitative Methods
Courses.Description:
Application of inferential statistics and sampling methods to sociological research.

Students who have previous credit in Sociology 4307 may not take Sociology 4317 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: SOCI 3311 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Society, Culture and Nature
Courses.Description: An examination of how classical and contemporary sociological theorists have conceptualized nature and our relationship to it, including the environment, technology, and other aspects of the nonhuman world.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: SOCI 1100 or ENST/GEOG 1120 or ENST/GEOG 1140 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Introduction to Social Welfare
Courses.Description: An in-depth exploration of the experience of poverty and Canada's social welfare system - specifically the income security programs offered as part of that system. We will examine the income security-related social policy and social programs that underlie the Canadian social welfare system. Attention is given to the history of society's response to meeting human need and to the various philosophical and theoretical perspectives and motivations for social welfare. We will look at how the social welfare system works, how it became what it is today, who makes decisions about it, what theories and approaches inform those decisions, and why certain vulnerable populations within our society are more likely to make use of it. Attention will be given to key concepts including oppression and social justice.

Courses.Title: Found of Social Work Practice
Courses.Description:
An introduction to the foundational theoretical and practice dimensions that contribute to and define the profession of social work. The social contexts and challenges of individuals, groups, and communities will be considered by reference to several of the diverse populations served by social work. An introduction will be provided to the broad range of service approaches that support a generalist social work practice in Canadian society. 

Students with previous credit for Social Work 2401 cannot take Social Work 2011/2012 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Social Work 1100 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Human Development
Courses.Description:
An introduction to theories and concepts that have been developed to explain human development from birth through to old age. An exploration of the physical, cognitive, socio-emotional and relational aspects of development over the lifespan. The major emphasis of the course is on the implications of developmental issues for social work practice.

Students with previous credit for Social Work 2401 cannot take Social Work 2011/2012 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Social Work 1100 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Soc Work Interviewing & Comm I
Courses.Description:
Provides students with the opportunity to understand and learn preparatory skills of communication and interviewing as part of their emerging social work practice. One's values, attitudes and beliefs as well as an understanding, appreciation and respect for cultural diversity will be emphasized. From an ecological and experiential approach, students will be introduced to exercises on verbal/non-verbal communications, professional relationships, mutuality and social work ethics. 

This course is restricted to third year Social Work Students only.

Courses.Title: Soc Work Interviewing & Com II
Courses.Description:
Provides students with the opportunity to understand and learn foundational skills of communication and interviewing as part of their emerging social work practice. In addition, students will learn about the professional and ethical use of self in their social work practice. One's values, attitudes and beliefs as well as an understanding, appreciation and respect for cultural diversity will be emphasized. Particular attention is devoted to the application of relationship and communication theories and how critical these theories are to social work practice. 

May only be taken by students enroled in the 3rd year of the Social Work program.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Social Work 3215 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Theory Soc Work Prac I
Courses.Description:
This professional practice theory course is designed to provide students with an introduction to selected major clinical theories that inform clinical social work practice with individuals and families. Students are introduced to how these clinical theories can enhance social work practice.

May only be taken by students enroled in the 3rd or 4th year of the Social Work program or the One Year Social Work program. Students in the One Year HBSW program must be concurrently enrolled or have completed SOWK 2011 and SOWK 2012.

Courses.Title: Field Instruction I
Courses.Description:
A field practicum to offer planned and supervised social work practice experience in an approved agency or organization. This opportunity and the required integrative learning activities will allow students to apply the theories and principles learned in the classroom to develop basic competence in generalist social work practice. System levels may focus on individuals, families, groups, or communities as a learning experience. The student will spend the equivalent of 50 days in the field work experience. 

Note 1: One Year students must complete a total of 700 hours (100 days) as the requirement for a combined placement (Social Work 3500 and 4501) in the same setting. May be taken by 3rd year and One year Social Work students only.  Note 2: Students may consider challenging Social Work 3500 with appropriate work experience/prior placements and social work supervision  Note 3: 3rd Year students must have completed SOWK 3401 and SOWK 3215 prior to beginning SOWK 3500. 3rd Year students must be currently enrolled in SOWK 3315.  Note 4: One Year students must have completed SOWK 3401 and be currently enrolled in SOWK 4300 and SOWK 4407

Courses.Title: Life Course Studies
Courses.Description: See Department of Sociology, Sociology Courses, Sociology 3515, for full course description.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take SOCI 1100 or GERO 1110 and GERO 1130 or SOWK 1100
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Soc Policy & Soc Welfare
Courses.Description:
Examination of in-depth approaches to policy making and critical analysis of selected welfare policies in Canada on municipal, provincial and national levels.

May only be taken by students enroled in the 4th year of the Social Work program or students in the One-Year Social Work program.

Courses.Title: Theory of Social Work Practice
Courses.Description:
Focuses on theories and their applications relevant to the practice of macro social work related to community work, organizations, and programming. The course incorporates a variety of perspectives and applications. 

This course is restricted to students enroled in the One Year Social Work program only.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Social Work 3401 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Theory Soc Work Prac II
Courses.Description:
Focuses on theories and their applications relevant to the practice of macro social work related to community work, organizations, and programming. The course incorporates a variety of perspectives and applications. 

This course may only be taken by fourth year Social Work students.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: SOWK 3401 and 3500 need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take SOWK-4500
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Research in Social Work
Courses.Description:
Provides students with a basic understanding of: the issues surrounding conceptualization, creation and utilization of knowledge and empirical evidence; the main quantitative and qualitative research methodologies; and the role of research in professional social work practice. Emphasis is placed on research design, including the development of research questions and objectives, conducting comprehensive literature reviews, completing the research ethics process, and collecting and analyzing data. This course will introduce basic statistics including measures of central tendency, variability, and association, significance tests, and statistical analysis. In addition, qualitative approaches to social work research will be explored including but not limited to grounded theory, phenomenology, ethnography, case study and narrative research. A critical examination of selected research materials in the field of social work will be used to appraise research as an integral component of social work practice and competency.

Note 1: Students may apply for exemption from Social Work 4405 if they have completed 1 FCE in research courses covering both statistics and research methodology with an average of 70% or higher. If exempted, Social Work 4405 must be replaced by 1 FCE of Social Work elective courses. Note 2: May only be taken by students enroled in the 4th year of the Social Work program or students in the One-Year Social Work program.

Courses.Title: Soc Work Interview Comm I & II
Courses.Description:
Provides students with the opportunity to understand and learn foundational skills of communication and clinical interviewing as part of their emerging social work practice. In addition, students will learn about the professional and ethical use of self in their social work practice. One's values, attitudes and beliefs as well as an understanding, appreciation and respect for cultural diversity will be emphasized. Students will be introduced to the fundamental components of an intake/assessment interview and write-up, treatment planning, the process of change, and termination. Particular attention is devoted to the importance of the therapeutic alliance, relationship, and communication/ listening skills. Also, selected major theoretical models and evidence based theoretical concepts that enhance clinical social work practice/interviewing will be addressed. The course will also introduce students to the major mental health/clinical issues clients typically present and will discuss their impact on clinical interviewing. 

This course is restricted to students admitted into the one-year Social Work program.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: SOWK 4300 needs to be registered for or completed to take  this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: SOWK 3401 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Soc Work Prac & Indigenous Peo
Courses.Description:
Designed to promote an awareness, understanding, and appreciation for Indigenous peoples. Emphasis will be on culture, values, beliefs, and appropriate intervention strategies for social workers in terms of knowledge, skills, and methods. Issues of social policy, programs and services, and the practice of social work in Indigenous communities will be explored. Indigenous involvement, participation, and culture are important dimensions to this course.

Students who have previous credit in Social Work 3411/Indigenous Learning 3411 may not take Social Work 4411/Indigenous Learning 4411 for credit. Note: Students completing this course will have fulfilled the Indigenous Content Requirement for Social Work.

Courses.Title: Field Instruction II
Courses.Description:
A supervised social work practice experience in an approved setting is combined with integrative seminars for deepening and refining the students' knowledge and skills in social work intervention at various system levels. The continued focus through this practice experience and the required learning activities will be toward competence development in generalist social work practice. Students will spend an equivalent of three days per week in field practicum for a total of sixty days (420 hours) throughout the fall/winter term.

Students who have taken Social Work 4501 may not take Social Work 4500 for credit. May only be taken by students in the Four Year Social Work program

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Social Work 3500 and 3315 need to be completed to take this  course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take SOWK-4401
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Field Instruction II
Courses.Description:
A supervised social work practice experience in an approved setting is combined with integrative seminars for deepening and refining the students' knowledge and skills in social work intervention at various system levels. The continued focus through this practice experience and the required learning activities will be toward competence development in generalist social work practice. Students will spend a total of fifty days (350 hours) in field placement during the spring term when combined with a 50 day 3500 winter practicum, at the same agency.

May only be taken by students in the One-Year Social Work program. One Year students must complete a total of 700 hours (100 days) as the requirement for a combined placement (Social Work 3500, 4501) in the same setting. If a student has been approved to do a split One Year placement, or has successfully challenged the Social Work 3500 course, the student will be required to spend the equivalent of 60 days (420 hours) in the field work experience for Social Work 4501. Students who have taken Social Work 4500 may not taken 4501 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Social Work 3500, 4407 and 4300 need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Special Topics I
Courses.Description: A seminar course specifically designed to provide students with the opportunity to investigate topics of special interest.

Courses.Title: University Seminar
Courses.Description:
Investigation of a topic using a multidisciplinary approach in a small group setting as an introduction to scholarship at the university level. The focus of each First Year Seminar course will vary. Topics will be studied using a variety of learning methods. The development of academic knowledge and skills, such as the use of library resources and research materials, writing a learned paper, and giving an oral presentation, will be fostered. Students will be exposed to the different scientific fields and careers in science and the seminars will provide exposure to the options within the Lakehead Science One program.

Students may only take one of UNIV-1010, 1011, 1012, 1013, 1014, 1015, 1016.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: UNIV 1015L needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: University Seminar
Courses.Description:
Investigation of a topic using a multidisciplinary approach in a small group setting as an introduction to scholarship at the university level. The focus of each First Year Seminar course will vary. Topics will be studied using a variety of learning methods. The development of academic knowledge and skills, such as the use of library resources and research materials, writing a learned paper, and giving an oral presentation, will be fostered. 

Students may only take one of UNIV-1010, 1011, 1012, 1013, 1014, 1015, 1016.

Courses.Title: Introductory Painting
Courses.Description:
A studio for beginners exploring traditional and abstract approaches to acrylic painting. Projects will introduce the study of composition, value, colour, and application of materials.

Enrolment limit: 25

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU-0511 needs to be registered for to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Special Topics Studio
Courses.Description:
An in-depth exploration of an area of studio practice. The topic will be announced by the Department in advance.

Enrolment limited to 15

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU-0511 needs to be registered for to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Introductory Sculpture
Courses.Description:
An introduction to basic vocabulary, concepts and processes of three-dimensional form.

Enrolment limit: 15

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU-0511 needs to be registered for to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Introductory Ceramics
Courses.Description:
An introduction to the techniques of handbuilding and throwing on the potter's wheel designed to familiarize the students with the nature of clay. The course includes clay and glaze decorating techniques as well as the loading and firing of kilns.

Enrolment limit: 15

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU-0511 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Introductory Drawing
Courses.Description:
An introductory course exploring a wide range of traditional and contemporary approaches to drawing. Through a series of studio assignments and illustrated lectures, students will learn to use various drawing materials and techniques to examine the fundamental elements of visual communication such as line, tone, shading and composition.

Enrolment limit: 25. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 1020 may not take Visual Arts 1150/1170 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU-0511 needs to be registered for at the same time
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

Courses.Title: Intermediate Drawing, Part I
Courses.Description:
Explores contemporary and traditional approaches to different methods of drawing. Various methods of figure drawing based on direct observations and other research will be addressed.

Enrolment limit 25. Students who have a previous credit in Visual Arts 2021 may not take Visual Arts 2010/2011 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU 1150 or 1170 need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Intermediate Drawing, Part II
Courses.Description:
Drawing with an emphasis on alternative methods and unconventional tools. Includes observational studies of the human form.

Enrolment limit 25. Students who have a previous credit in Visual Arts 2021 may not take Visual Arts 2010/2011 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU 2010 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Intermediate Painting, Part I
Courses.Description:
An exploration of contemporary painting with a focus on colour, composition, and the review of painting materials and techniques.

Enrolment limit 25. Students who have a previous credit in Visual Arts 2041 may not take Visual Arts 2014/2015 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU 1010 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Intermediate Painting, Part II
Courses.Description:
A project based approach to studio painting with a focus on understanding theories of art as they relate to contemporary trends in painting.

Enrolment limit 25. Students who have a previous credit in Visual Arts 2041 may not take Visual Arts 2014/2015 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU 2014 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Intermediate Ceramics, Part I
Courses.Description:
Covers hand-building techniques using different clay bodies. Includes the study of contemporary ceramic practices for clay manipulation, glaze mixing and surface treatments. Participating in the kiln firing process is an integral part of the course.

Enrolment limit 15. Students who have a previous credit in Visual Arts 2101 may not take Visual Arts 2110/2111 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU 1050 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Intermediate Ceramics, Part II
Courses.Description:
Further development of clay working skills for hand-building sculptural forms and enhancing techniques for wheel-throwing. Glaze chemistry and non-traditional surface treatments will also be explored.

Enrolment limit 15. Students who have a previous credit in Visual Arts 2101 may not take Visual Arts 2110/2111 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU 2110 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Intermediate Sculpture, Part I
Courses.Description:
Study of the techniques and methods used for the production of studio sculpture. Covers fabrication with mold making and casting materials and construction methods for using soft and rigid materials.

Enrolment limit 15. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 2121 may not take Visual Arts 2112/2113 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU 1030 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Intermediate Sculpture, Pt II
Courses.Description:
Concepts in contemporary art will be applied to studio assignments for creating sculpture.

Enrolment limit 15. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 2121 may not take Visual Arts 2112/2113 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: VISU 2112 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Advanced Sculpture Part 1
Courses.Description:
An in-depth study of the materials and processes used to create contemporary sculpture. Students will further develop skills for mold making, casting, fabrication and woodworking along with the application of ready-made objects. Important themes in contemporary art will be covered as the foundation for studio assignments. 

Enrolment limit 15. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 3001 may not take Visual Arts 3011/3012 for credit

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Visual Arts 2113 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Advanced Sculpture 2
Courses.Description:
A series of studio projects following a thematic approach, determined in consultation with the instructor. Also examines best practices for exhibiting three-dimensional art in both traditional gallery spaces and non-traditional display settings.

Enrolment limit 15. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 3001 may not take Visual Arts 3011/3012 for credit

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Visual Arts 3011 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Advanced Drawing Part 1
Courses.Description:
An advanced study of drawing from observation, memory, research, and imagination. Emphasis is placed on drawing from the live model and anatomy with a focus on observational drawing. Development of the technical and aesthetic skills required for effective self-expression are explored and an individual drawing series is introduced.

Enrolment limit 15. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 3021 may not take Visual Arts 3013/3014

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Visual Arts 2011 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Advanced Drawing Part 2
Courses.Description:
Continues the application of techniques and concepts from observation and imagination. Emphasis is placed on the development of the language of drawing, mark making as an individualized tool, and non-traditional techniques and approaches. An independent series is further developed and presentation issues are considered. 

Enrolment limit 15. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 3021 may not take Visual Arts 3013/3014 for credit

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Visual Arts 3013 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Advanced Painting Part 1
Courses.Description:
An advanced study of painting based on research and observation. Explores the importance of concepts in relation to contemporary painting and the role of aesthetic skills in the development of subject matter. Individual skills are developed through a series of guided projects.

Enrolment limit 20. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 3041 may not take Visual Arts 3015/3016 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Visual Arts 2015 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Advanced Painting Part 2
Courses.Description:
An advanced study of painting that focuses on the development of painterly skills through research-based projects. Explores the relationship between the meaning of the produced image and the intentions of the artist through the creation of a series of works of art. The painterly methods of modern and contemporary artists will also be examined.

Enrolment limit 20. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 3041 may not take Visual Arts 3015/3016 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Visual Arts 3015 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Advanced Ceramics Part 1
Courses.Description:
Covers advanced techniques for hand building and wheel throwing clay with emphasis on developing an individual expression of form. Examines glaze technology and firing kilns as an integral part of working in ceramics.

Enrolment limit 15. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 3101 may not take Visual Arts 3110/3111 for credit

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Visual Arts 2111 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Advanced Ceramics Part 2
Courses.Description:
Continues the practice of mastering various techniques used for working with clay. Students will also focus on developing a conceptual framework through a series of studio assignments covering planning, production, and the final presentation of works of art. 

Enrolment limit 15. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 3101 may not take Visual Arts 3110/3111 for credit

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Visual Arts 3110 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Internship
