Courses.Description: The purpose of this course is to provide the student with work experience in an art-related setting. This may involve work in the area of commercial or applied art or other media-based industries, volunteer or paid labour in an art gallery setting, assisting in the teaching of art classes, tutoring in art, or other appropriate work experiences. Work experiences are recorded in a journal. Students have the option of producing a significant paper of sufficient length on a relevant topic. Specific assignments will be arranged for each student.

Courses.Title: Senior Sculpture Part 1
Courses.Description:
An advanced and intensive exploration of the student's chosen medium. Students are expected to produce a significant body of exhibition quality works of art following an individualized outline decided in consultation with the instructor. 

Enrolment limit 15. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 4003 may not take Visual Arts 4011/4012 for credit

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Visual Arts 3012 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Senior Sculpture Part 2
Courses.Description:
Students are expected to produce a significant body of exhibition quality works of art continuing the individualized outline established in 4011 and decided in consultation with the instructor. Coursework will be selected as part of a group exhibition for a degree-culminating art exhibition. 

Enrolment limit is 15. Students who have previous credit in Visual Arts 4001 may not take Visual Arts 4011/4012 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Visual Arts 4011 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Professional Practices in Art
Courses.Description:
Outlines the methods of sustaining an art practice as a visual artist. Following a review of the Canadian gallery structure, students will explore strategies for self-promotion by preparing a curriculum vitae, learning about photo and video documentation, online promotion and creating a public profile, and writing an application cover letter. Topics also include grants and grant writing for visual artists, establishing a studio business, graduate studies, studio residencies, and other opportunities for artists. 

Enrolment limit 15. Students must have fourth year standing in the Visual Arts Honours program. Students who have a previous credit in Visual Arts 4130 may not take Visual Arts 4017 for credit.

Courses.Title: Field School
Courses.Description:
Students will receive lab instruction and conduct field exercises in dendrology and forest mensuration for four days prior to the start of fall classes.

A non-credit required course for the Specialization in Applied Environmental Water Management only. An additional field trip fee is required for this course.

Courses.Title: Environ Sci Field Course I
Courses.Description:
Provides students with practical hands -on experience in field and laboratory techniques in environmental science. In the field, students will use a variety of tools and techniques to sample water, sediments, soils, and vegetation. Samples will be analyzed in a laboratory facility and the students will interpret their results and prepare a final report. The two week course will be held immediately prior to the start of the Fall term.

Enrollment restricted to HBESc, HBES and Water Resource Science majors in their third or fouth year, except with permission of the program committee for the Division of Environmental Studies or Director of Water Resource Science program. An additional fee (see Miscellaneous Fees) is required for this course.

Courses.Title: Honours Thesis
Courses.Description: Qualifying students must arrange for a thesis topic and supervisor (a program committee member) during the third year of their program. The honours project will permit the student to perform research in his/her specialized area of interest under the supervision of the faculty member most proficient in this field. The project will entail field and/or laboratory work, as well as library research and will culminate with the production of an undergraduate thesis.

Courses.Title: Women's and Gender Studies
Courses.Description:
An interdisciplinary introduction, the course explores intersections of gender, race, class, sexuality, ability, age and other socially/historically shaped dimensions of identity. Discussions will include such topics as media, health, work, poverty, body and sexuality, violence, law and creativity, in local and global contexts.

Gender and Women's Studies Core Course or Gender and Women's Studies Group 1 Course

Courses.Title: Body Politics
Courses.Description: The body is situated as a site of political, ethical, and feminist potential, while also addressing the history of patriarchal control over (women's) bodies. Through practices of modification, bodies can be made and remade to suit individual and/or social needs or desires. Feminist theories of the body are analyzed and critiqued as practices that produce, alter, and transform individual bodies. Particular attention will be paid to practices of regulation and forms of resistance. Investigate the body as a site of personal power, and explore methods of body modification including (but not limited to) tattooing, cosmetic surgery, gender transitions, and birth control.

Courses.Title: Horror Films and Feminism
Courses.Description:
A study of horror films as cultural narratives that support and/or challenge hierarchies of gender as it intersects with race, class, sexuality, age, and other identity positions. A study of feminist film theories such as cultural, psychoanalytic, audience response, and queer feminist film studies to analyze the films. Emphasis will be placed on developing the ability to read, interpret, and analyze the role that horror, as a genre, plays in the cultural reproduction of gender-linked hierarchies, and how feminist-linked horror films challenge traditional cultural tropes that define women, mothers, and the feminized as uncanny, unnatural, or just plain evil.

Gender and Women's Studies Core Course or Gender and Women's Studies Group 1 Course. Students who have previously taken Women's Studies 2111 Horror Films and Feminism cannot take Gender and Women's Studies 2035 for credit.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: WOME 1100 needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Transnational Masculinities
Courses.Description:
Feminist studies of masculinity are integrative, interdisciplinary, and transnational. An in-depth examination of the relational nature of masculinity and how hegemonic masculinity is produced through institutions like sports, media, military, family, religion, and nationhood. Central to analysis will be how a web of masculinities produces different outcomes for men based on their race, age, class, sexuality, ability, and positioning within transnational politics and economies. 

Gender and Women's Studies Core Course or Gender and Women's Studies Group 1 Course

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: 2 FCE in Women's Studies, including at least 0.5 FCE at the  2nd year level, need to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Global Reproductive Justice
Courses.Description:
A transnational feminist examination of reproductive practices, issues, and policies using a reproductive justice framework. Under this framework, there are three areas of focus: (1) the right not to have a child; (2) the right to have a child; (3) the right to parent children in safe and healthy environments. With a focus on cross cultural reproductive practices, topics will include prenatal care and birthing; use and regulation of reproductive technologies; child welfare and state intervention; neoliberalism, globalization, and the reproductive body. 

Gender and Women's Studies Core Course or Gender and Women's Studies Group 1 Course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: 2 FCE in Women's Studies, including at least 0.5 FCE at the  2nd year level, needs to be completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Women, Gender & Social Justice
Courses.Description:
Advanced colloquium for fourth-year Gender and Women's Studies students. Contemporary issues in the field of gender and women's studies will be explored. The specific thematic focus of the course will be negotiated annually in relation to student interests.

Gender and Women's Studies Core Course or Gender and Women's Studies Group 1 Course

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: 2 FCE in Women's Studies, including at least one half-course at the 3rd year level need to be completed to take this  course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

Courses.Title: Women & Legal Narratives
Courses.Description:
A feminist analysis of legal themes in contemporary and canonical popular literary texts. This course explores the relationship between literature and law, and examines how both structure women's legal identities as they intersect with race, class, ability, age and sexuality from the early-modern period to the present day.

Gender and Women's Studies Core Course or Gender and Women's Studies Group 1 Course

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: 2 FCE in Women's Studies and/or Criminology, including at  least one half-course at the 3rd year level need to be  completed to take this course
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.
